description: Used to introduce the concept of observing the moon and noticing its changing appearance in the sky.
An overview diagram showing all eight phases of the moon in their cyclical order, illustrating the entire process at a glance.
The first phase. Visually represented as a blank or dark circle to show that the moon is not visible from Earth.
A diagram showing the Sun, Moon, and Earth in a line (Sun-Moon-Earth) to explain why the New Moon is not illuminated from our perspective.
A diagram illustrating the concept of 'waxing,' where the visible, illuminated portion of the moon grows from right to left (in the Northern Hemisphere).
The second phase. A thin sliver of the moon is illuminated on the right side.
The third phase. Exactly the right half of the moon is illuminated.
The fourth phase. More than half of the moon is illuminated on the right side, but it is not yet full.
The fifth phase. The entire face of the moon is illuminated, appearing as a complete circle.
A diagram illustrating the concept of 'waning,' where the illuminated portion of the moon shrinks, with the left side remaining lit (in the Northern Hemisphere).
The sixth phase. More than half of the moon is illuminated, but the light is now receding from the right, leaving the left side lit.
The seventh phase. Exactly the left half of the moon is illuminated.
The eighth and final phase. A thin sliver of the moon is illuminated on the left side before it disappears into the New Moon phase again.
